DESC.Contact Network:
The Contact Network graph model describes all social interactions:
  • Nodes represent individuals in the population
  • Edges represent all interactions across which the pathogen can transmit
  • Currently, FAVITES-Lite only supports static (i.e., unchanging) contact networks
DESC.Transmission Network: The Transmission Network compartmental model describes how the pathogen propagates along the contact network. State transition rates are in unit of Poisson process arrivals per time (reciprocal of expected time to next arrival). The user will specify the number of individuals in each compartment, and individuals will be placed into each compartment uniformly.
DESC.Sample Times: The Sample Times model describes the time(s) at which individuals in the transmission network are sampled (i.e., sequenced).
DESC.Viral Phylogeny (Transmissions): The Viral Phylogeny (Transmissions) coalescent model describes the topology and branch lengths (in unit of time) of the viral phylogeny throughout the epidemic, which is constrained by the transmission network.
DESC.Viral Phylogeny (Seeds): The Viral Phylogeny (Seeds) phylogenetic model describes the topology and branch lengths (in unit of time) of the viral phylogeny prior to the epidemic (i.e., the viral phylogeny of the seed individuals).
DESC.Mutation Rates: The Mutation Rates model describes how mutation rates (i.e., mutations/time) are sampled along each branch of the viral time phylogeny.
DESC.Ancestral Sequence: The Ancestral Sequence model describes how the ancestral (i.e., root) sequence is generated/selected.
DESC.Sequence Evolution: The Sequence Evolution model describes how sequences evolve down the phylogeny.

m.DESC: Number of edges attached from new nodes to existing nodes

Barabasi-Albert (BA).DESC: The Barabasi-Albert (BA) model is an algorithm for generating undirected random scale-free networks using a preferential attachment mechanism.
Barabasi-Albert (BA).CITE: • Albert R, Barabasi AL (2002). "Statistical mechanics of complex networks." Rev Mod Phys. 74(1):47-97. doi:10.1103/RevModPhys.74.47
PROP: The total number of edges is: m(n-m)
The expected degree is approximately: 2m

m1.DESC: Number of nodes in each of the two complete subgraphs

m2.DESC: Number of nodes in the path connecting the two complete subgraphs

Barbell.DESC: A barbell graph is an undirected graph composed of two complete graphs, each with m1 nodes, connected by a path of m2 nodes.
Barbell.CITE: • Ghosh A, Boyd S, Saberi A (2006). "Minimizing Effective Resistance of a Graph." Proc 17th Internat Sympos Math Th Network and Systems. 1185-1196. doi:10.1137/050645452
PROP: The total number of nodes is: 2m1 + m2
The total number of edges is: m1(m1-1) + m2 + 1

Complete.DESC: A complete graph is a simple undirected graph in which every pair of distinct vertices is connected by a unique edge.
PROP: The total number of edges is: n choose 2 = n(n-1)/2
The degree of every node (and thus also the average degree) is: n-1

Cycle.DESC: A cycle graph is an undirected graph that consists of a single cycle. In other words, the vertices are connected in a closed chain.
PROP: When n > 2, the number of edges is: n

p.DESC: Probability of existence of an edge

Erdos-Renyi (ER).DESC: The Erdos-Renyi (ER) model is an undirected graph model in which each of the n choose 2 possible edges have probability p of existing.
Erdos-Renyi (ER).CITE:
• Erdos P, Renyi A (1959). "On Random Graphs. I." Publ Math. 6:290-297.
  • Gilbert EN (1959). "Random Graphs." Ann Math Stat. 30(4):1141-1144. doi:10.1214/aoms/1177706098
PROP: The expected degree is: p(n choose 2) = pn(n-1)/2
The degree distribution is: Binomial(n-1, k)

k.DESC: Number of nearest neighbors to connect to

p.DESC: Probability of adding a new edge

Newman-Watts-Strogatz (NWS).DESC:
The Newman-Watts-Strogatz (NWS) model is an undirected graph model as follows:
  1. Start with a ring of n nodes
  2. Connect each node with its k nearest neighbors
  3. For each edge (u,v) in the ring, add a new random edge (u,w) with probability p
Newman-Watts-Strogatz (NWS).CITE: • Newman MEJ, Watts DJ (1999). "Renormalization group analysis of the small-world network model." Phys Lett A. 263(4-6):341-346. doi:10.1016/S0375-9601(99)00757-4
PROP: The number of edges in the connected ring is: nk/2
The number of newly added edges is: Binomial(nk/2, p)

Path.DESC: A path graph (or linear graph) is an undirected graph whose nodes can be ordered in a line, and there exists an edge between every adjacent pair of nodes.
PROP: The number of edges is: n-1

k.DESC: Number of nearest neighbors to connect to

Ring Lattice.DESC: A ring lattice graph is an undirected graph in which every node has an edge to each of its k nearest neighbors.
PROP: The number of edges is: nk/2

N_NS.DESC: The number of individuals in state NS at the start of the simulation

N_S.DESC: The number of individuals in state S at the start of the simulation

N_I1.DESC: The number of individuals in state I1 at the start of the simulation

N_I2.DESC: The number of individuals in state I2 at the start of the simulation

N_I3.DESC: The number of individuals in state I3 at the start of the simulation

N_I4.DESC: The number of individuals in state I4 at the start of the simulation

N_A1.DESC: The number of individuals in state A1 at the start of the simulation

N_A2.DESC: The number of individuals in state A2 at the start of the simulation

N_A3.DESC: The number of individuals in state A3 at the start of the simulation

N_A4.DESC: The number of individuals in state A4 at the start of the simulation

N_D.DESC: The number of individuals in state D at the start of the simulation

R_S-I1.DESC: The transition rate S → I1 (nodal, e.g. outside infection)

R_S-I1_I1.DESC: The transition rate S → I1 induced by neighbors in I1

R_S-I1_I2.DESC: The transition rate S → I1 induced by neighbors in I2

R_S-I1_I3.DESC: The transition rate S → I1 induced by neighbors in I3

R_S-I1_I4.DESC: The transition rate S → I1 induced by neighbors in I4

R_S-I1_A1.DESC: The transition rate S → I1 induced by neighbors in A1

R_S-I1_A2.DESC: The transition rate S → I1 induced by neighbors in A2

R_S-I1_A3.DESC: The transition rate S → I1 induced by neighbors in A3

R_S-I1_A4.DESC: The transition rate S → I1 induced by neighbors in A4

Granich et al. (2008).DESC:
The Granich et al. (2008) model for HIV has 11 states:
  • NS: Non-Susceptible
  • S: Susceptible
  • I1, I2, I3, and I4: Untreated HIV stage 1, 2, 3, and 4
  • A1, A2, A3, and A4: ART-treated HIV stage 1, 2, 3, and 4
  • D: Deceased
The following transitions are possible:
  • NS → S (nodal)
  • S → I1 (induced by I1-I4/A1-A4 or outside)
  • I1 → A1, I2 → A2, I3 → A3, and I4 → A4 (nodal)
  • A1 → I1, A2 → I2, A3 → I3, and A4 → I4 (nodal)
  • I1 → I2 → I3 → I4 (nodal)
  • A1 → A2 → A3 → A4 (nodal)
  • All non-D states → D
Granich et al. (2008).CITE: • Granich RM, Gilks CF, Dye C, De Cock KM, Williams BG (2008). "Universal voluntary HIV testing with immediate antiretroviral therapy as a strategy for elimination of HIV transmission: a mathematical model." The Lancet. 373(9657):48-57. doi:10.1016/S0140-6736(08)61697-9

N_MA.DESC: The number of individuals in state MA at the start of the simulation

N_FA.DESC: The number of individuals in state FA at the start of the simulation

R_FS-FIA.DESC: The transition rate FS → FIA (nodal, e.g. outside infection)

R_FS-FIA_MIS.DESC: The transition rate FS → FIA induced by neighbors in MIS

R_FS-FIA_FIS.DESC: The transition rate FS → FIA induced by neighbors in FIS

R_FS-FIA_FIA.DESC: The transition rate FS → FIA induced by neighbors in FIA

Hethcote and Yorke (1984).DESC:
The Hethcote and Yorke (1984) model for gonorrhea has 8 states:
  • MA and FA: Male/Female Abstinent
  • MS and FS: Male/Female Susceptible
  • MIS and FIS: Male/Female Symptomatic Infected
  • MIA and FIA: Male/Female Asymptomatic Infected
The following transitions are possible:
  • MA → MS and FA → FS (nodal)
  • MS → MA and FS → FA (nodal)
  • MS → MIA and FS → FIA (induced by MIA/MIS/FIA/FIS or outside)
  • MS → MIS and FS → FIS (induced by MIA/MIS/FIA/FIS or outside)
  • MIA → MS and FIA → FS (nodal)
  • MIS → MS and FIS → FS (nodal)
Must select "None" for all downstream steps.
Hethcote and Yorke (1984).CITE: • Hethcote HW, Yorke JA (1984). "Gonorrhea transmission dynamics and control." Lect Notes Math. 56. doi:10.1007/978-3-662-07544-9

None.DESC: No transmission network is simulated. Must select "None" for all downstream steps.

N_S.DESC: The number of individuals in state S at the start of the simulation

N_A.DESC: The number of individuals in state A at the start of the simulation

N_P.DESC: The number of individuals in state P at the start of the simulation

N_H.DESC: The number of individuals in state H at the start of the simulation

N_I.DESC: The number of individuals in state I at the start of the simulation

R_S-E.DESC: The transition rate S → E (nodal, e.g. outside infection)

R_S-E_E.DESC: The transition rate S → E induced by neighbors in E

R_S-E_P.DESC: The transition rate S → E induced by neighbors in P

R_S-E_I.DESC: The transition rate S → E induced by neighbors in I

R_S-E_A.DESC: The transition rate S → E induced by neighbors in A

SAPHIRE.DESC:
The SAPHIRE model (Hao et al., Nature 2020) has 7 states:
  • S: Susceptible
  • A: Unascertained Case
  • P: Presymptomatic Infectious Case
  • H: Hospitalized Case
  • I: Ascertained Infectious Case
  • R: Removed
  • E: Exposed
The following transitions are possible:
  • S → E (induced by E/P/I/A or outside)
  • E → P (nodal)
  • P → A and P → I (nodal)
  • I → H and I → R (nodal)
  • A → R (nodal)
  • H → R (nodal)
SAPHIRE.CITE: • Hao X, Cheng S, Wu D, Wu T, Lin X, Wang C (2020). "Reconstruction of the full transmission dynamics of COVID-19 in Wuhan." Nature. 584:420-424. doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2554-8

N_S.DESC: The number of individuals in state S at the start of the simulation

N_A1.DESC: The number of individuals in state A1 at the start of the simulation

N_A2.DESC: The number of individuals in state A2 at the start of the simulation

N_P1.DESC: The number of individuals in state P1 at the start of the simulation

N_P2.DESC: The number of individuals in state P2 at the start of the simulation

N_H.DESC: The number of individuals in state H at the start of the simulation

N_I1.DESC: The number of individuals in state I1 at the start of the simulation

N_I2.DESC: The number of individuals in state I2 at the start of the simulation

R_S-E_P1.DESC: The transition rate S → E induced by neighbors in P1

R_S-E_P2.DESC: The transition rate S → E induced by neighbors in P2

R_S-E_I2.DESC: The transition rate S → E induced by neighbors in I2

R_S-E_A1.DESC: The transition rate S → E induced by neighbors in A1

R_S-E_A2.DESC: The transition rate S → E induced by neighbors in A2

SAAPPHIIRE.DESC:
The SAAPPHIIRE model (Pekar et al., Science 2022) has 10 states:
  • S: Susceptible
  • A1 and A2: Unascertained Case (Stage 1 and Stage 2)
  • P1 and P2: Presymptomatic Infectious Case (Stage 1 and Stage 2)
  • H: Hospitalized Case
  • I1 and I2: Ascertained Infectious Case (Stage 1 and Stage 2)
  • R: Removed
  • E: Exposed
The following transitions are possible:
  • S → E (induced by E/P1/P2/I1/I2/A1/A2 or outside)
  • E → P1 (nodal)
  • P1 → P2 (nodal)
  • P2 → A1 and P2 → I1 (nodal)
  • I1 → I2 and I1 → H(nodal)
  • I2 → H and I2 → R (nodal)
  • A1 → A2 (nodal)
  • A2 → R (nodal)
  • H → R (nodal)
SAAPPHIIRE.CITE: • Pekar JE, Magee A, Parker E, Moshiri N, Izhikevich K, Havens JL, Gangavarapu K, Malpica Serrano LM, Crits-Christoph A, Matteson NL, Zeller M, Levy JI, Wang JC, Hughes S, Lee J, Park H, Park MS, Ching Zi Yan K, Tzer Pin Lin R, Mat Isa MN, Muhammad Noor Y, Vasylyeva TI, Garry RF, Holmes EC, Rambaut A, Suchard MA, Andersen KG, Worobey M, Wertheim JO (2022). "The molecular epidemiology of multiple zoonotic origins of SARS-CoV-2." Science. 377(6609):960-966. doi:10.1126/science.abp8337

N_S.DESC: The number of individuals in state S at the start of the simulation

N_A.DESC: The number of individuals in state A at the start of the simulation

N_I.DESC: The number of individuals in state I at the start of the simulation

R_S-A_I.DESC: The transition rate S → A induced by neighbors in I

R_S-I.DESC: The transition rate S → I (nodal, e.g. outside infection)

R_S-I_I.DESC: The transition rate S → I induced by neighbors in I

R_A-I.DESC: The transition rate A → I (nodal, e.g. outside infection)

R_A-I_I.DESC: The transition rate A → I induced by neighbors in I

Susceptible-Alert-Infected-Susceptible (.DESC:
The Susceptible-Alert-Infected-Susceptible (SAIS) model has three states:
  • S: Susceptible
  • A: Alert
  • I: Infected
The following transitions are possible:
  • S → A (nodal or induced by A or I)
  • S → I (induced by I or outside)
  • A → I (induced by I or outside)
  • I → S (nodal)

N_S.DESC: The number of individuals in state S at the start of the simulation

N_E.DESC: The number of individuals in state E at the start of the simulation

N_I.DESC: The number of individuals in state I at the start of the simulation

N_R.DESC: The number of individuals in state R at the start of the simulation

R_S-E.DESC: The transition rate S → E (nodal, e.g. outside infection)

R_S-E_I.DESC: The transition rate S → E induced by neighbors in I

Susceptible-Exposed-Infected-Removed (SE.DESC:
The Susceptible-Exposed-Infected-Removed (SEIR) model has four states:
  • S: Susceptible
  • E: Exposed
  • I: Infected
  • R: Removed
The following transitions are possible:
  • S → E (induced by I or outside)
  • E → I (nodal)
  • I → R (nodal)

N_S.DESC: The number of individuals in state S at the start of the simulation

N_I.DESC: The number of individuals in state I at the start of the simulation

R_S-I.DESC: The transition rate S → I (nodal, e.g. outside infection)

R_S-I_I.DESC: The transition rate S → I induced by neighbors in I

Susceptible-Infected (SI).DESC:
The Susceptible-Infected (SI) model has two states:
  • S: Susceptible
  • I: Infected
The following transition is possible:
  • S → I (induced by I or outside)

N_S.DESC: The number of individuals in state S at the start of the simulation

N_I.DESC: The number of individuals in state I at the start of the simulation

N_R.DESC: The number of individuals in state R at the start of the simulation

R_S-I.DESC: The transition rate S → I (nodal, e.g. outside infection)

R_S-I_I.DESC: The transition rate S → I induced by neighbors in I

Susceptible-Infected-Removed (SIR).DESC:
The Susceptible-Infected-Removed (SIR) model has three states:
  • S: Susceptible
  • I: Infected
  • R: Removed
The following transitions are possible:
  • S → I (induced by I or outside)
  • I → R

N_S.DESC: The number of individuals in state S at the start of the simulation

N_I.DESC: The number of individuals in state I at the start of the simulation

R_S-I.DESC: The transition rate S → I (nodal, e.g. outside infection)

R_S-I_I.DESC: The transition rate S → I induced by neighbors in I

Susceptible-Infected-Susceptible (SIS).DESC:
The Susceptible-Infected-Susceptible (SIS) model has two states:
  • S: Susceptible
  • I: Infected
The following transitions are possible:
  • S → I (induced by I or outside)
  • I → S

sampled_states.DESC: Comma-separated list of states in which individuals are sampled

num_samples.DESC: The number of times every individual is sampled

End.DESC: All individuals who are in any of the specified states at the end time of the simulation will be sampled the specified number of times.

None.DESC: No individuals are sampled. Must select "None" for all downstream steps.

sampled_states.DESC: Comma-separated list of states in which individuals are sampled

sample_time.DESC: The time at which individuals are sampled

num_samples.DESC: The number of times every individual is sampled

Specific Time.DESC: All individuals who are in any of the specified states at a specified time will be sampled the specified number of times.

sampled_states.DESC: Comma-separated list of states in which individuals are sampled

State Entry (All).DESC: Individuals are sampled every time they enter any of the specified states. Individuals who never enter any of the specified states are never sampled.

sampled_states.DESC: Comma-separated list of states in which individuals are sampled

State Entry (Initial).DESC: Individuals are sampled the first time they enter any of the specified states. Individuals who never enter any of the specified states are never sampled.

sampled_states.DESC: Comma-separated list of states in which individuals are sampled

num_samples.DESC: The number of times every individual is sampled

Truncated Exponential.DESC: Each sample time of a given individual is sampled from a "standardized form" Truncated Exponential distribution of the individual's infection time window. If the individual has multiple time windows, a single time window is chosen randomly with equal probability.

sampled_states.DESC: Comma-separated list of states in which individuals are sampled

num_samples.DESC: The number of times every individual is sampled

k.DESC: Shape parameter of the Gamma distribution

theta.DESC: Scale parameter of the Gamma distribution

Truncated Gamma.DESC: Each sample time of a given individual is sampled from a Truncated Gamma distribution of the individual's time window of specified states. If the individual has multiple time windows, a single time window is chosen randomly with equal probability.

sampled_states.DESC: Comma-separated list of states in which individuals are sampled

num_samples.DESC: The number of times every individual is sampled

mu.DESC: Location parameter (i.e., mode) of the Truncated Normal distribution

sigma.DESC: Scale parameter of the Truncated Normal distribution

Truncated Normal.DESC: Each sample time of a given individual is sampled from a Truncated Normal distribution of the individual's infection time window. If the individual has multiple time windows, a single time window is chosen randomly with equal probability.
PROP: To center the underlying Normal at the center of the [0,1] window: mu = 0.5
To center the underlying Normal at the left of the [0,1] window: mu = 0
To center the underlying Normal at the right of the [0,1] window: mu = 1

sampled_states.DESC: Comma-separated list of states in which individuals are sampled

num_samples.DESC: The number of times every individual is sampled

Uniform.DESC: Each sample time of a given individual is sampled from a Uniform distribution of the individual's infection time window. If the individual has multiple time windows, a single time window is chosen randomly with equal probability.

Constant Effective Population Size.DESC: The effective intra-host viral population size is constant.

Infection Time.DESC: Coalescent events occur as early in time as possible.

None.DESC: No phylogeny is simulated. Must select "None" for all downstream steps.

Transmission Tree.DESC: Coalescent events occur as late in time as possible.

Coalescent (Neutral).DESC: The seed tree is sampled from a Neutral Coalescent model and is scaled to the specified height.

r.DESC: The ratio lambda_a / lambda_b (i.e., activation rate / birth rate)

Dual-Birth.DESC: The seed tree is sampled from a Dual-Birth model (Moshiri & Mirarab, Syst Biol 2018) and is scaled to the specified height.
Dual-Birth.CITE: Moshiri N, Mirarab S (2018). "A Two-State Model of Tree Evolution and Its Applications to Alu Retrotransposition." Syst Biol. 67(3):475-489. doi:10.1093/sysbio/syx088

rate_func.DESC: The rate function f(t) of the initial Non-Homogeneous Yule tree

Non-Homogeneous Yule.DESC:
The seed tree is sampled from a Non-Homogeneous Yule model with rate_func f(t) and is scaled to the specified height.

Must select "None" for all downstream steps.

WARNING: This plugin uses eval() to execute f(t), which is unsafe!!! Don't use a config file that uses this plugin without verifying!

None.DESC: No phylogeny is simulated. Must select "None" for all downstream steps.

Yule.DESC: The seed tree is sampled from a Yule model (Yule, Phil Trans Royal Soc London 1925) and is scaled to the specified height.
Yule.CITE: Yule (1925). "II.—A mathematical theory of evolution, based on the conclusions of Dr. J. C. Willis, F. R. S." Phil Trans Royal Soc London. 213:21-87. doi:10.1098/rstb.1925.0002

R0.DESC: The mutation rate of the root edge

delta.DESC: The amount a rate can change from parent to child

p.DESC: The probability that a child branch will have a different rate than its parent

Autocorrelated Constant Increment.DESC:
Each branch's length is multiplied by one of the following rates:
  • The rate of its parent, with probability 1-p
  • The rate of its parent + delta, with probability p/2
  • The rate of its parent - delta, with probability p/2
  • The root edge has rate R0
  • All rates must be in the range [R_min, R_max]
Autocorrelated Constant Increment.CITE: Sanderson MJ (1997). "A Nonparametric Approach to Estimating Divergence Times in the Absence of Rate Constancy." Mol Biol Evol. 14(12):1218. doi:10.1093/oxfordjournals.molbev.a025731

R0.DESC: The mutation rate of the root edge

Autocorrelated Exponential.DESC: Each branch's length is multiplied by a rate that is sampled from an Exponential distribution whose mean is the rate of the parent branch.
Autocorrelated Exponential.CITE: Aris-Brosou S, Yang Z (2002). "Effects of Models of Rate Evolution on Estimation of Divergence Dates with Special Reference to the Metazoan 18S Ribosomal RNA Phylogeny." Syst Biol. 51(5):703-714. doi:10.1080/10635150290102375

R0.DESC: The mutation rate of the root edge

v.DESC: Scaling factor of the Gamma distribution's variance

Autocorrelated Gamma.DESC: Each branch's length is multiplied by a rate that is sampled from a Gamma distribution whose mean is the rate of the parent branch and whose variance is the branch length multiplied by v.
Autocorrelated Gamma.CITE: Aris-Brosou S, Yang Z (2002). "Effects of Models of Rate Evolution on Estimation of Divergence Dates with Special Reference to the Metazoan 18S Ribosomal RNA Phylogeny." Syst Biol. 51(5):703-714. doi:10.1080/10635150290102375

R0.DESC: The mutation rate of the root edge

v.DESC: Scaling factor of the Log-Normal distribution's variance

Autocorrelated Log-Normal.DESC: Each branch's length is multiplied by a rate that is sampled from a Log-Normal distribution whose mean is the rate of the parent branch and whose variance is the branch length multiplied by v.
Autocorrelated Log-Normal.CITE: Aris-Brosou S, Yang Z (2002). "Effects of Models of Rate Evolution on Estimation of Divergence Dates with Special Reference to the Metazoan 18S Ribosomal RNA Phylogeny." Syst Biol. 51(5):703-714. doi:10.1080/10635150290102375

k.DESC: Degrees of freedom of the Chi-Squared distribution

Chi-Squared.DESC: Each branch's length is multiplied by a rate that is sampled from a Chi-Squared distribution with k degrees of freedom.

Constant.DESC: Each branch's length is multiplied by a constant rate.

beta.DESC: Scale parameter of the Exponential distribution

Exponential.DESC: Each branch's length is multiplied by a rate that is sampled from an Exponential distribution with scale parameter beta.

d1.DESC: Degrees of freedom in the F distribution's numerator

d2.DESC: Degrees of freedom in the F distribution's denominator

F.DESC: Each branch's length is multiplied by a rate that is sampled from an F distribution with degrees of freedom parameters d1 and d2.

k.DESC: Shape parameter of the Gamma distribution

theta.DESC: Scale parameter of the Gamma distribution

Gamma.DESC: Each branch's length is multiplied by a rate that is sampled from a Gamma distribution with shape parameter k and scale parameter theta.

mu.DESC: Mean of the Inverse Gaussian (Wald) distribution

lambda.DESC: Shape parameter of the Inverse Gaussian (Wald) distribution

Inverse Gaussian (Wald).DESC: Each branch's length is multiplied by a rate that is sampled from an Inverse Gaussian (Wald) distribution with mean mu and shape parameter lambda.

mu.DESC: Mean of the underlying Normal distribution

sigma.DESC: Standard deviation of the underlying Normal distribution

Log-Normal.DESC: Each branch's length is multiplied by a rate that is sampled from a Log-Normal distribution with mean mu and standard deviation sigma.

k.DESC: Degrees of freedom of the Noncentral Chi-Squared distribution

lambda.DESC: Non-centrality parameter of the Noncentral Chi-Squared distribution

Noncentral Chi-Squared.DESC: Each branch's length is multiplied by a rate that is sampled from a Noncentral Chi-Squared distribution with k degrees of freedom and non-centrality parameter lambda.

d1.DESC: Degrees of freedom in the Noncentral F distribution's numerator

d2.DESC: Degrees of freedom in the Noncentral F distribution's denominator

lambda.DESC: Non-centrality parameter of the Noncentral F distribution

Noncentral F.DESC: Each branch's length is multiplied by a rate that is sampled from a Noncentral F distribution with degrees of freedom parameters d1 and d2, and with non-centrality parameter lambda.

None.DESC: No mutation rates are sampled (i.e., no mutation tree is output). Must select "None" for all downstream steps.

alpha.DESC: Shape parameter of the Pareto distribution

Pareto.DESC: Each branch's length is multiplied by a rate that is sampled from a Pareto distribution with shape parameter alpha.

c.DESC: Shape parameter of the Power distribution

Power.DESC: Each branch's length is multiplied by a rate that is sampled from a Power distribution with shape parameter c.

sigma.DESC: Scale parameter of the Rayleigh distribution

Rayleigh.DESC: Each branch's length is multiplied by a rate that is sampled from a Rayleigh distribution with scale parameter sigma.

Triangular.DESC: Each branch's length is multiplied by a rate that is sampled from a Triangular distribution with lower-limit a, upper-limit b, and mode c.

mu.DESC: Location parameter of the Truncated Normal distribution

sigma.DESC: Scale parameter of the Truncated Normal distribution

a.DESC: Minimum of the Truncated Normal distribution

b.DESC: Maximum of the Truncated Normal distribution

Truncated Normal.DESC: Each branch's length is multiplied by a rate that is sampled from a Truncated Normal distribution with location parameter mu, scale parameter sigma, minimum a, and maximum b.

Uniform.DESC: Each branch's length is multiplied by a rate that is sampled from a Uniform distribution with minimum a and maximum b.

shape.DESC: Shape parameter of the Weibull distribution

scale.DESC: Scale parameter of the Weibull distribution

Weibull.DESC: Each branch's length is multiplied by a rate that is sampled from a Weibull distribution with shape parameter shape and scale parameter scale.

Exact Base Frequencies.DESC: The ancestral sequence is randomly generated with the exact user-provided base frequencies (as proportions).

Base Probabilities.DESC: Each letter of the ancestral sequence is randomly selected according to the user-provided base probabilities.

None.DESC: No ancestral sequence is simulated. Must select "None" for all downstream steps.

r_A-C.DESC: Transition rate between A and C

r_A-G.DESC: Transition rate between A and G

r_A-T.DESC: Transition rate between A and T

r_C-G.DESC: Transition rate between C and G

r_C-T.DESC: Transition rate between C and T

r_G-T.DESC: Transition rate between G and T

General Time-Reversible (GTR).DESC: Sequences evolve according to a General Time-Reversible (GTR) substitution model.
General Time-Reversible (GTR).CITE: Tavaré S (1986). "Some Probabilistic and Statistical Problems in the Analysis of DNA Sequences." Lect Math Life Sci. 17:57–86.

r_A-C.DESC: Transition rate between A and C

r_A-G.DESC: Transition rate between A and G

r_A-T.DESC: Transition rate between A and T

r_C-G.DESC: Transition rate between C and G

r_C-T.DESC: Transition rate between C and T

r_G-T.DESC: Transition rate between G and T

r_site1.DESC: Relative rate of substitution at codon site 1

r_site2.DESC: Relative rate of substitution at codon site 2

r_site3.DESC: Relative rate of substitution at codon site 3

General Time-Reversible (GTR) + Codon.DESC: Sequences evolve according to a General Time-Reversible (GTR) substitution model with codon-specific rate heterogeneity.
General Time-Reversible (GTR) + Codon.CITE: Tavaré S (1986). "Some Probabilistic and Statistical Problems in the Analysis of DNA Sequences." Lect Math Life Sci. 17:57–86.

r_A-C.DESC: Transition rate between A and C

r_A-G.DESC: Transition rate between A and G

r_A-T.DESC: Transition rate between A and T

r_C-G.DESC: Transition rate between C and G

r_C-T.DESC: Transition rate between C and T

r_G-T.DESC: Transition rate between G and T

alpha.DESC: Shape parameter of Gamma model of rate heterogeneity

num_cats.DESC: Number of categories in discrete Gamma model (or 0 for continuous)

General Time-Reversible (GTR) + Gamma.DESC: Sequences evolve according to a General Time-Reversible (GTR) substitution model with Gamma-distributed rate heterogeneity.
General Time-Reversible (GTR) + Gamma.CITE: Tavaré S (1986). "Some Probabilistic and Statistical Problems in the Analysis of DNA Sequences." Lect Math Life Sci. 17:57–86.
